comment: I am not sure that his resoning with m and n  being same as money is correct. Using dubling the money when we loose, straregy we can make probability to loose arbitrarly low depending on ratio money to risk vs money to win . For example if we bring 700$ trying to win 100$,  only way we loose all this money is to loose 3 times in a row and this gets approx 15% to loose and 85% to win. Our expected value is still negative, that mean that we expect to loose in the long run, but more money we are willing to risk,  better our winning odds can be.

Today, gambling has become a key means for money laundering. Players intentionally lose millions and millions of dollars so that the casino will take away some share and return to the player the rest. Bitcoin and restaurants are other means of money laundering. Rather than taking on the guilt and sin of evil, isn't the pleasure of learning math purer and cleaner?

Great course. Here’s my personal experience from this course: 1. It took me around 5 months to finish this course. With 1-2 lectures per week. I have been reading all the reading material up until lecture 17-18, after that only partially or not at all. Tried all Recitations and reviewed all  answers. Problem sets: did around 8/12. No idea how correct they were though. Found readings to be a bit excessive and problem sets a bit discouraging to solve. Answers to problems would have been nice I think. 2. As for material presentation: Number theory - the part that I I joined the least. Counting & probability. I felt like I needed a lot more exercises to try myself to get used to concepts.   Overall - amazing. Thanks for the course.

I followed the whole series and I love Professor Leighton, but I have to point out that he made an unrealistic assumption when proving gambler's ruin problem. The wrong assumption is: every bet is $1. If I increase the bet unit to, say, $100, that obviously leads to a very different answer. He actually proved that the probability of winning 100 TIMES, is, well, understandably, small. In reality, people place $20-$50 is not uncommon. (I'm not his mother-in-law. ;P)
Thanks Prof. Leighton for always being very engaging. Fantastic course, thanks MIT OCW for the great content.
Great Lecturer.

It 100% matters on what you want. I am in the same place as you, not yet in college. If you want to go to the next level in cs, this is the 1st course to take for sure in order to open yourself up to the more complex ideas in all other courses for complex cs.

I'm a business informatics student so I am taking introduction to computer science and computer programming,  and so far I hate everything that has to do with this major aside from these 2 courses which I am really enjoying so far, so I am considering changing to a computer science and engineering major,  but I want to make sure this is what I will enjoy before I make this change so I am researching some stuff  relating to computer science online, one of which being discrete mathematics.  Do you think discrete maths gives good insight on how CS is like?  How about 'Theory of computation' and 'Intro to Artificial Intelligence'?  Do you have any other recommendations for courses or subjects that DO give good insight on CS and  do not have any course prerequisites so I can look into them and be able to follow? Thanks in advance to those  who take the time to answer and help :) Apologies if this has spammed you on more than one video. I'm just trying to get as much information as possible.

Bravo to djbl4090 ... with a smarter betting strategy, the mother-in-law  turns out to be cleverer than her mathematical son-in-law.  The key is to always bet $100 more than the amount already lost.  That is, her first bet is $100: if it comes up red, she wins and stops.  If it doesn't come up red, the next time she bets $200.  If it comes up non-red again, she bets $400 the third time.  The chances of it coming up non-red three times in row is only 0.1457, which means she is very likely to win $100 starting with $1000.  Starting with an even larger amount, she is almost certain to win.  Moral: don't fight city hall, and especially don't fight your mother-in-law.  She'll win every time.
